text: hi my name is Dave pay and I'm a senior
product manager on the AWS ec2 Windows
team in this video I will introduce AWS
tools for Powershell and then show how
to install set up your aw's credentials
and then give you a brief tour of the
Powershell tools we built these tools
for Powershell admins and developers who
want to accomplish quick actions when
working in a Powershell command line or
want to connect and manage AWS services
using Powershell scripts we do have some
requirements these tools will work on
Windows XP or higher with Powershell 2.0
or higher so let's get started and see
how to install the
tools AWS tools for Powershell can be
downloaded from aws.amazon.com
for/ Power Cell here I've already
downloaded the install file to start the
installation double click the
installation file first click
next next read through the licensing
agreement and then check the box if you
accept the agreement and then click next
you can select what components and where
you would like to install the files go
ahead and click next when you ready
click install
shortly the tools will be installed and
click finish to close the install
wizard now let's walk through how to set
up your AWS credentials if you're using
a Windows Server 2012 go to the start
page and there you will find the AWS
Powershell unlike the windows Powershell
this one has the AWS module imported and
ready to use to set up your AWS
credentials we run initialize AWS
defaults this commandlet will ask you
for for your AWS access key Seeker key
and finally a default region if you need
these Keys the AWS web console has them
under security credentials here I'm
entering some demo keys and then I
select Us West for my
region now AWS tools for Powershell is
set up and ready to interact with AWS
Services let's continue with the tour of
the tools first let's discover what's
provided to do this we'll use the PO
shell command get command and the AWS
power shell as the module as you can see
there's lots of commands over 500
commands that control AWS
Services now let's use help to find all
the ec2 instance commands to learn more
about a specific command L we'll use
help and this time we'll use the tab
completion feature to switch through the
command lits okay I found the get ec2
instance command and help provides us
with a help page with the command lit
and parameters you can set now let's run
the get ec2 instance command instead of
showing a long list of ec2 details I'm
going to type the output to the
Powershell format table this provides us
with a nice table output that is easier
to read we can also ask get ec2 instance
for all running instances to do this we
surround get ec2 instance in parentheses
and then aen running instance this time
I'm going to pipe it to format it as a
list and then use more to pause it when
the output fills the screen as I scroll
through the results you can see relevant
e AWS instance information like instance
ID instance size IP address and subnet
information now let's try transferring
files to an S3 storage bucket first let
me show you the file structure on the
server I have a folder called my folder
of files and within that I have a
structure of folders and files in this
demo docs and pictures and inside the
doc folder I have an archive folder and
a file called Doc 1.txt and a text file
in the archive folder called doc 2 a
similar structure for the pictures
folder first let's see what's in my S3
bucket using the get S3 bucket command I
have two buckets let's create a new
bucket using the new S3 bucket command
and Define the bucket name parameter as
PST test
bucket now when I run get S3 bucket we
see three
buckets with the bucket created we can
upload the entire folder of files that I
showed earlier to S3 using the recurse
flag the right S3 object command takes
care of mapping the local folder
hierarchy to a path key for the object
stored on S3 as I type on the command
line I'm also using tab completion on
the parameters we'll use the PS test
bucket and then Define the key prefix as
my folder of files the folder parameter
is the foldo location that I showed
earlier and finally the recurse
parameter Now using the get S3 object
commandlet I can get a list of all the
items in the PS test bucket I specified
earlier okay that list went by really
fast let's switch over to the AWS
console to view the three bucket and
files now on the AWS console I see the
PS test bucket in the folder my folder
of files and inside that folder I have
the docs and pictures folders inside of
the docs folder I have an archive folder
and a text file docs one.txt and finally
docs 2 in the archive folder for the
final demo let's take a look at how a
script can better integrate Windows
management with your AWS management
Tools in this Powershell script we will
track a Windows performance counter in
cloudwatch so that we can see it along
with our other AWS service metrics sh
lets us create net objecting with the
AWS SDK for net here I'm using the sdk's
cloudwatch class metric datam to create
a data point object called that next I
set up the object with the Tim stamp the
metric name total system threads and
finally a unit called count on the next
two lines I populate the object with the
values pulled from a Windows performance
counter and then save it to cloudwatch
using the right CW metric command L this
script is also wrapped in a do Loop to
provide plenty of data for the cloud
watch metric graph now we're back in the
Powershell console I'll go ahead and
start the
script here you can see that the script
is started and you can see the Windows
system values to see the results let's
switch over to the AWS web console to
see what this metric looks like in the
metric viewing drop down you can see the
windows metric which is created by the
script next you can see and select the
total system threads and finally you can
see the timebase graph for the total
system threads below and mouse over each
data point to see more details about the
actual value and time
this gives you a quick tour of what you
can do with the new AWS tools for
Powershell for more information or to
download please visit our online
developer Center at aws.amazon.com
Powershell
